metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Characteristics of the carbon atom that contribute to the diversity of organic compounds formed, with reference to valence electron number, relative bond strength, relative stability of carbon bonds with other elements, degree of unsaturation (carbon-carbon double bonds), and the formation of structural isomers

valence_electron_number.name: Valence Electron Number
valence_electron_number.correct: Carbon has 4 valence electrons in its outermost shell, allowing it to form exactly 4 covalent bonds.

2 valence electrons.error: That is the number for group 2 elements like beryllium.
2 valence electrons.fix: Carbon is in group 14. The group number minus 10 gives valence electrons for groups 13-18.
2 valence electrons.action: Look at the periodic table. Carbon is in group 14, so it has 14 - 10 = 4 valence electrons.

6 valence electrons.error: You are thinking of the total electron number, not valence electrons.
6 valence electrons.fix: Valence electrons are only in the outermost shell. Carbon has 2 in shell 1, 4 in shell 2.
6 valence electrons.action: Write carbon's electron configuration: 1s² 2s² 2p². Only count shell 2.

3 valence electrons.error: That is the number for group 13 elements like boron.
3 valence electrons.fix: Carbon is one group to the right of boron, so it has one more valence electron.
3 valence electrons.action: Check: does carbon form 3 bonds or 4 bonds in methane (CH₄)?

persistent.gap: You are confusing total electrons with valence electrons.
persistent.action: Practice: Write electron configurations for C, N, O, and F. For each, identify only the outermost shell electrons.

carbon_bonding_capacity.name: Carbon Bonding Capacity
carbon_bonding_capacity.correct: Carbon always forms exactly 4 covalent bonds to achieve a stable octet configuration.

3 covalent bonds.error: With 3 bonds, carbon would have only 7 electrons in its outer shell.
3 covalent bonds.fix: Carbon needs 8 electrons total (octet rule). 4 from itself + 4 shared = 8.
3 covalent bonds.action: Draw methane (CH₄). Count the bonds from the central carbon atom.

2 covalent bonds.error: That is too few bonds to satisfy carbon's octet.
2 covalent bonds.fix: Carbon with 4 valence electrons needs to share 4 more to reach 8.
2 covalent bonds.action: Draw carbon dioxide (CO₂). The carbon has 2 double bonds = 4 bonds total.

5 covalent bonds.error: Carbon cannot form 5 bonds. This would exceed the octet rule.
5 covalent bonds.fix: Carbon has only 4 valence electrons available for bonding.
5 covalent bonds.action: Try drawing carbon with 5 bonds. You will find it is impossible.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why valence electrons limit bonding capacity.
persistent.action: Draw Lewis structures for CH₄, CO₂, and C₂H₆. Verify carbon has exactly 4 bonds in each.

carbon_chain_formation.name: Carbon Chain Formation
carbon_chain_formation.correct: Carbon can bond to other carbon atoms to form chains and rings, creating structural diversity.

only bond to hydrogen.error: This would limit organic compounds to just one molecule: methane.
only bond to hydrogen.fix: Carbon can bond to itself (catenation) and to H, O, N, halogens, and more.
only bond to hydrogen.action: Look at ethane (C₂H₆). The two carbons are bonded to each other.

form only single bonds.error: Carbon can also form double and triple bonds.
form only single bonds.fix: Carbon forms single (C-C), double (C=C), and triple (C≡C) bonds.

only form chains.error: Carbon can also form ring structures.
only form chains.fix: Cyclic structures like cyclohexane and benzene contain carbon rings.
only form chains.action: Draw cyclohexane. Notice the carbons form a closed ring.

persistent.gap: You are not seeing the full diversity of carbon bonding.
persistent.action: Draw examples of: a chain (butane), a ring (cyclohexane), and a compound with a double bond (propene).

bond_energy_concept.name: Bond Energy Concept
bond_energy_concept.formula: Higher bond energy = stronger bond = more stable
bond_energy_concept.correct: Bond energy is the energy required to break one mole of bonds. Higher bond energy means a stronger, more stable bond.

energy released when bond forms.error: That describes bond formation, not bond strength.
energy released when bond forms.fix: Bond energy specifically measures breaking bonds, not making them.
energy released when bond forms.action: Think: you must add energy to break a bond. That added energy is the bond energy.

lower bond energy means more stable.fix: A bond requiring MORE energy to break is MORE stable.
lower bond energy means more stable.action: Compare: Which is harder to break - a door held by a weak latch or a strong lock?

independent of bond type.error: Single, double, and triple bonds have different energies.
independent of bond type.fix: More bonds between atoms = higher bond energy.
independent of bond type.action: Compare C-C (347 kJ/mol) vs C=C (614 kJ/mol) vs C≡C (839 kJ/mol).

persistent.gap: You are not connecting bond energy to bond stability.
persistent.action: Memorise: High bond energy → hard to break → stable. Low bond energy → easy to break → less stable.

multiple_bond_energy.name: Multiple Bond Energy
multiple_bond_energy.correct: Triple bonds have the highest bond energy, followed by double bonds, then single bonds.

single bonds are strongest.error: Single bonds have the lowest bond energy of the three.
single bonds are strongest.fix: More bonds = more electrons shared = more energy needed to break.
single bonds are strongest.action: Compare: C-C (347 kJ/mol), C=C (614 kJ/mol), C≡C (839 kJ/mol).

all bonds have equal energy.error: Bond energy varies significantly with bond order.
all bonds have equal energy.fix: A double bond is almost twice as strong as a single bond.
all bonds have equal energy.action: Calculate: 614 ÷ 347 ≈ 1.8. A C=C is about 1.8 times stronger than C-C.

double bonds are strongest.error: Triple bonds require more energy to break than double bonds.
double bonds are strongest.fix: Three shared electron pairs are stronger than two.
double bonds are strongest.action: Compare C≡C (839 kJ/mol) with C=C (614 kJ/mol). Which is higher?

persistent.gap: You do not see how bond order affects stability.
persistent.action: Create a table: Single/Double/Triple bonds with their approximate energies. See the pattern.

bond_stability_atomic_radius.name: Bond Stability and Atomic Radius
bond_stability_atomic_radius.formula: Smaller atom = shorter bond = stronger bond
bond_stability_atomic_radius.correct: Bonds to smaller atoms are generally stronger because the bond length is shorter and electron sharing is more effective.

larger atoms form stronger bonds.error: Larger atoms form longer, weaker bonds.
larger atoms form stronger bonds.fix: Smaller atomic radius = shorter bond = stronger overlap = stronger bond.
larger atoms form stronger bonds.action: Compare C-F (485 kJ/mol) with C-I (240 kJ/mol). Fluorine is smaller than iodine.

atomic size does not affect bond strengt.error: Bond length directly affects bond energy.
atomic size does not affect bond strengt.fix: Longer bonds (from larger atoms) have weaker electron sharing.
atomic size does not affect bond strengt.action: Look at the halogen series: C-F > C-Cl > C-Br > C-I in bond energy. Atoms get larger.

all C-halogen bonds have equal strength.error: Each halogen gives a different bond energy with carbon.
all C-halogen bonds have equal strength.fix: Going down group 17, atomic radius increases and C-X bond strength decreases.
all C-halogen bonds have equal strength.action: Compare: C-F (485 kJ/mol), C-Cl (339 kJ/mol), C-Br (276 kJ/mol), C-I (240 kJ/mol).

persistent.gap: You do not understand how atomic size affects bond properties.
persistent.action: Draw a diagram showing how larger atoms create longer bonds with less orbital overlap.

saturated_definition.name: Saturated vs Unsaturated
saturated_definition.formula: Saturated = all single bonds; Unsaturated = has double/triple bonds
saturated_definition.correct: A saturated molecule has only single bonds between carbons. An unsaturated molecule has at least one C=C double bond or C≡C triple bond.

saturated means has double bonds.error: This is the opposite. Saturated means no double or triple bonds.
saturated means has double bonds.fix: Saturated means the carbon is bonded to the maximum number of atoms - no room for more.
saturated means has double bonds.action: Compare: saturated ethane (C₂H₆) vs unsaturated ethene (C₂H₄). Ethane has more H atoms.

unsaturated means ring structure.error: Rings affect degree of unsaturation but are not the definition.
unsaturated means ring structure.fix: Unsaturated specifically refers to C=C or C≡C bonds.
unsaturated means ring structure.action: Cyclohexane is a ring but is saturated (no double bonds). Cyclohexene has a double bond.

saturated means fully oxidised.error: You are confusing saturation with oxidation.
saturated means fully oxidised.fix: Saturation is about bond types, not oxidation states.
saturated means fully oxidised.action: In organic chemistry, saturated = all single bonds. Ignore oxidation numbers here.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the term 'saturated' with other concepts.
persistent.action: Remember: saturated = full of hydrogens = no double bonds. Like a sponge saturated with water - no room for more.

degree_of_unsaturation_concept.name: Degree of Unsaturation Concept
degree_of_unsaturation_concept.correct: Degree of unsaturation counts the number of double bonds and ring structures in a molecule.

only counts double bonds.error: Ring structures also contribute to degree of unsaturation.
only counts double bonds.fix: Each ring reduces the hydrogen count by 2, just like a double bond does.
only counts double bonds.action: Compare C₆H₁₂ (cyclohexane, DoU=1) with C₆H₁₄ (hexane, DoU=0). The ring counts.

counts oxygen atoms.error: Oxygen does not directly affect the degree of unsaturation calculation.
counts oxygen atoms.fix: DoU is about hydrogen deficiency due to rings and multiple bonds.
counts oxygen atoms.action: Both ethanol (C₂H₆O) and ethane (C₂H₆) have DoU=0. The oxygen does not change it.

counts all bonds.error: Only double bonds and rings contribute, not single bonds.
counts all bonds.fix: Single C-C bonds do not reduce hydrogen count.
counts all bonds.action: Compare butane (C₄H₁₀, DoU=0) with butene (C₄H₈, DoU=1). Only the double bond counts.

persistent.gap: You do not understand what causes hydrogen deficiency in molecules.
persistent.action: Practice: For molecules with DoU>0, identify whether the unsaturation is from double bonds, rings, or both.

dou_calculation.name: DoU Calculation
dou_calculation.correct: Degree of unsaturation can be calculated from the molecular formula using: DoU = (2C + 2 + N - H - X) / 2, where X = halogens.

(2C + 2 + N + H) / 2.error: Hydrogens should be subtracted, not added.
(2C + 2 + N + H) / 2.fix: More hydrogens means less unsaturation. Hydrogens reduce the DoU.
(2C + 2 + N + H) / 2.action: Compare C₂H₆ (DoU=0) with C₂H₄ (DoU=1). Less H = higher DoU.

(C + 2 + N - H) / 2.error: Missing the factor of 2 before carbon.
(C + 2 + N - H) / 2.fix: Each carbon can hold 2 hydrogens in a saturated chain, so multiply C by 2.
(C + 2 + N - H) / 2.action: Apply the correct formula to ethane: (2×2 + 2 - 6) / 2 = 0. It works.

C + 2 - H.error: This formula is incomplete and not divided by 2.
C + 2 - H.fix: The division by 2 is essential because each ring or double bond removes 2 hydrogens.
C + 2 - H.action: Double bonds remove 2 H atoms. So we divide by 2 to count them.

persistent.gap: You have not memorised the DoU formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write: DoU = (2C + 2 + N - H - X) / 2. Practice with ethane, ethene, and benzene.

structural_isomer_definition.name: Structural Isomer Definition
structural_isomer_definition.formula: Same molecular formula, different structural arrangement
structural_isomer_definition.correct: Structural isomers have the same molecular formula but different arrangements of atoms.

same structure, different formula.error: That would be different compounds entirely.
same structure, different formula.fix: Isomers must have identical molecular formulas - same atoms, different arrangement.
same structure, different formula.action: Butane and 2-methylpropane both have C₄H₁₀ but different structures.

molecules drawn differently.error: Drawing the same molecule in different orientations does not create isomers.
molecules drawn differently.fix: The atoms must actually be connected differently, not just rotated or flipped.
molecules drawn differently.action: Rotating a molecule 180° does not create an isomer. The bonds must change.

any molecules with similar properties.error: Isomers have the same formula, not just similar properties.
any molecules with similar properties.fix: The molecular formula must be identical. Properties can differ.
any molecules with similar properties.action: Ethanol and methoxymethane have similar properties but only methoxymethane is an isomer if formulas match.

persistent.gap: You do not understand what makes molecules isomers.
persistent.action: Key test: If molecular formula is identical AND structure differs, they are structural isomers.

skeletal_isomer.name: Skeletal Isomers
skeletal_isomer.correct: Skeletal isomers (chain isomers) have the same molecular formula but different carbon chain arrangements - straight vs branched.

same carbon chain, different groups.error: That describes positional isomers, not skeletal isomers.
same carbon chain, different groups.fix: Skeletal isomers differ in how the carbon backbone is arranged.
same carbon chain, different groups.action: Compare pentane (straight chain) vs 2-methylbutane (branched). Both are C₅H₁₂.

different molecular formulas.error: All isomers must have the same molecular formula.
different molecular formulas.fix: Skeletal isomers have identical formulas but the carbon skeleton differs.
different molecular formulas.action: Pentane and 2-methylbutane both have C₅H₁₂ but different carbon arrangements.

same as positional isomers.error: Skeletal and positional isomers are different types.
same as positional isomers.fix: Skeletal = different backbone. Positional = same backbone, different functional group position.
same as positional isomers.action: Classify: pentane vs 2-methylbutane (skeletal); pentan-1-ol vs pentan-2-ol (positional).

persistent.gap: You are confusing types of structural isomers.
persistent.action: Make a table: Skeletal (backbone differs), Positional (position differs), Functional (functional group differs).

positional_isomer.name: Positional Isomers
positional_isomer.formula: Same backbone, different functional group position
positional_isomer.correct: Positional isomers have the same molecular formula and carbon backbone but the functional group is attached at different positions.

different carbon chain length.error: That describes skeletal isomers, not positional isomers.
different carbon chain length.fix: Positional isomers have the same backbone - only the position of substitution changes.
different carbon chain length.action: Compare 1-chloropropane vs 2-chloropropane. Same backbone (propane), different Cl position.

different functional groups.fix: Positional isomers have the SAME functional group at different positions.
different functional groups.action: Pentan-1-ol and pentan-2-ol both have -OH, just at different carbons.

drawn from different angles.fix: The functional group must actually move to a different carbon atom.
drawn from different angles.action: Verify: Does the functional group attach to a different numbered carbon? If yes, positional isomer.

persistent.gap: You are not distinguishing between types of structural isomers.
persistent.action: For each isomer pair, ask: Same backbone? Same functional group? If both yes but different position = positional.

functional_group_isomer.name: Functional Group Isomers
functional_group_isomer.correct: Functional group isomers have the same molecular formula but contain different functional groups entirely.

same functional group at different posit.error: That describes positional isomers, not functional group isomers.
same functional group at different posit.fix: Functional group isomers have completely DIFFERENT functional groups.
same functional group at different posit.action: Compare propan-1-ol (alcohol, -OH) vs methoxyethane (ether, -O-). Both are C₃H₈O.

different molecular formulas.error: Isomers must have identical molecular formulas.
different molecular formulas.fix: The formula is the same; the functional groups are different.
different molecular formulas.action: Verify both molecules have the same number of C, H, and O atoms.

same as skeletal isomers.error: Skeletal isomers have the same functional group but different carbon backbone.
same as skeletal isomers.fix: Functional group isomers have different functional groups (e.g., alcohol vs ether).
same as skeletal isomers.action: Alcohol and ether have different chemistry. They are functional group isomers if formulas match.

persistent.gap: You cannot identify when molecules have different functional groups.
persistent.action: Learn to recognise functional groups: -OH (alcohol), -O- (ether), C=O (carbonyl), -COOH (carboxylic acid).

valence_bonding.title: Valence Electrons and Carbon Bonding
valence_bonding.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of carbon's bonding characteristics.

sentences.text: Carbon is located in group {{d1}} of the periodic table and has {{d2}} valence electrons in its outermost shell.

d1.tooltip: Look at the periodic table. Which group is carbon in?

d2.tooltip: Valence electrons are in the outermost shell only.

sentences.text: To achieve a stable octet configuration, carbon forms exactly {{d3}} covalent bonds, which can be single, double, or {{d4}} bonds.

d3.tooltip: How many valence electrons does carbon share?

d4.tooltip: Carbon can share up to 3 pairs of electrons with one atom.

sentences.text: Carbon's ability to bond to other carbon atoms is called {{d5}}, which allows the formation of long chains, branched structures, and {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: This term describes carbon bonding to itself in chains.

bond_strength.title: Bond Strength and Stability
bond_strength.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of bond energy and stability relationships.

sentences.text: Bond energy is defined as the energy required to {{d1}} one mole of bonds. A bond with {{d2}} bond energy is more stable.

d1.tooltip: Bond energy measures how much energy must be added, not released.

d2.tooltip: If it takes more energy to break, the bond is harder to break.

sentences.text: The C-C single bond has a bond energy of 347 kJ mol⁻¹, while the C=C double bond has a bond energy of {{d3}} kJ mol⁻¹, making the double bond {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Double bonds are approximately 1.8 times stronger than single bonds.

d4.tooltip: More shared electrons means more energy to separate.

sentences.text: When comparing C-F, C-Cl, C-Br, and C-I bonds, the {{d5}} bond is strongest because fluorine has the {{d6}} atomic radius.

d5.tooltip: Smaller atoms form shorter, stronger bonds.

d6.tooltip: Fluorine is at the top of group 17.

unsaturation.title: Understanding Degree of Unsaturation
unsaturation.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of saturation and unsaturation in organic molecules.

sentences.text: A saturated hydrocarbon contains only {{d1}} bonds between carbon atoms, while an unsaturated hydrocarbon contains at least one {{d2}} bond.

d1.tooltip: Saturated means full of hydrogens - no room for more.

d2.tooltip: Double bonds give unsaturation by reducing the hydrogen count.

sentences.text: The degree of unsaturation (DoU) counts the number of {{d3}} and {{d4}} structures in a molecule.

d3.tooltip: What type of bond reduces the hydrogen count?

d4.tooltip: Cyclic structures also reduce the hydrogen count by 2.

sentences.text: Cyclohexane (C₆H₁₂) has a DoU of {{d5}} because it contains one ring and {{d6}} double bonds.

d5.tooltip: One ring contributes one unit of unsaturation.

d6.tooltip: Cyclohexane is a saturated cyclic compound - all single C-C bonds.

structural_isomers.title: Understanding Structural Isomers
structural_isomers.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of structural isomers.

sentences.text: Structural isomers are molecules that have the same {{d1}} but different arrangements of {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Isomers must have identical atomic composition.

d2.tooltip: The same atoms are connected differently.

sentences.text: Skeletal isomers differ in the arrangement of the {{d3}}, such as butane (straight chain) and 2-methylpropane ({{d4}}).

d3.tooltip: Skeletal refers to the carbon skeleton of the molecule.

d4.tooltip: 2-methylpropane has a methyl group branching off the main chain.

sentences.text: Positional isomers have the same functional group located on {{d5}} carbon atoms, such as pentan-1-ol and {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The position changes, not the functional group itself.

d6.tooltip: The -ol suffix shows both are alcohols; the number shows position.

valence_bonding.title: Applying Carbon Bonding Concepts
valence_bonding.instructions: Apply your understanding of carbon's bonding to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The electron configuration of carbon is {{d1}}, with the 2s and 2p orbitals holding {{d2}} electrons available for bonding.

d1.tooltip: Carbon has 6 total electrons: 2 in the first shell, 4 in the second.

d2.tooltip: Count electrons in the outermost shell only.

sentences.text: In methane (CH₄), the carbon atom forms {{d3}} single bonds to hydrogen atoms, creating a {{d4}} molecular geometry.

d3.tooltip: Count the H atoms in CH₄.

d4.tooltip: Four bonding pairs around carbon adopt this shape.

sentences.text: Carbon can form long chains because C-C bonds are relatively {{d5}}, with a bond energy of {{d6}} kJ mol⁻¹.

d5.tooltip: C-C bonds are stable enough to form long molecules.

d6.tooltip: This is the average bond energy for C-C single bonds.

bond_strength.title: Comparing Bond Strengths
bond_strength.instructions: Apply your understanding of bond strength to compare different bonds.

sentences.text: The trend in bond energy for carbon-halogen bonds is C-F > C-Cl > C-Br > C-I because the {{d1}} increases down the group, making bonds {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What property of atoms increases going down a group?

d2.tooltip: Larger atoms form longer bonds with less orbital overlap.

sentences.text: A C≡C triple bond has a bond energy of approximately {{d3}} kJ mol⁻¹, which is {{d4}} than a double bond because more electrons are shared.

d3.tooltip: Triple bonds are the strongest carbon-carbon bonds.

d4.tooltip: More shared electrons require more energy to separate.

sentences.text: The C-O bond (358 kJ mol⁻¹) is {{d5}} than the C-N bond (305 kJ mol⁻¹) because oxygen is {{d6}} than nitrogen.

d6.tooltip: Oxygen is to the right of nitrogen in period 2.

unsaturation.title: Calculating Degree of Unsaturation
unsaturation.instructions: Apply the DoU formula and concepts to determine unsaturation.

sentences.text: The formula for degree of unsaturation is DoU = (2C + 2 + N - H - X) / 2. For C₄H₈, the DoU equals {{d1}}, indicating {{d2}} unit of unsaturation.

d2.tooltip: The calculated value tells you total rings plus double bonds.

sentences.text: Benzene (C₆H₆) has a DoU of {{d3}}, which accounts for one ring and {{d4}} double bonds in its structure.

d4.tooltip: Benzene has alternating single and double bonds around the ring.

sentences.text: Halogens like chlorine count as {{d5}} in the DoU formula, so C₃H₇Cl has the same DoU as {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Each halogen replaces one H, so they subtract the same way.

d6.tooltip: C₃H₇Cl = C₃H₇ + Cl, which equals C₃H₈ with one H replaced.

structural_isomers.title: Classifying Structural Isomers
structural_isomers.instructions: Apply your understanding to classify different types of structural isomers.

sentences.text: Pentane and 2-methylbutane are {{d1}} isomers because they have the same molecular formula (C₅H₁₂) but different {{d2}} arrangements.

d1.tooltip: The carbon backbone is different - straight vs branched.

d2.tooltip: Skeletal isomers differ in how the carbon chain is arranged.

sentences.text: Propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol are {{d3}} isomers because the hydroxyl group is bonded to {{d4}} carbon atoms.

d3.tooltip: Same functional group (-OH) at different positions.

d4.tooltip: The number in the name indicates which carbon has the -OH.

sentences.text: Ethanol (C₂H₅OH) and methoxymethane (CH₃OCH₃) are {{d5}} isomers because they contain different functional groups: {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The functional groups are completely different types.

valence_bonding.title: Mastering Carbon Bonding Principles
valence_bonding.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of why carbon's properties lead to organic diversity.

sentences.text: Carbon's unique ability to form diverse organic compounds stems from its {{d1}} valence electrons, which allow it to form {{d2}} covalent bonds without gaining or losing electrons to form ions.

d1.tooltip: This number equals carbon's bonding capacity.

d2.tooltip: Carbon shares all its valence electrons.

sentences.text: Unlike silicon (which also has 4 valence electrons), carbon forms {{d3}} C-C bonds that allow extensive chain formation, because carbon's {{d4}} atomic radius creates shorter, more stable bonds.

d3.tooltip: C-C bonds are strong enough for very long chains.

d4.tooltip: Carbon is in period 2, smaller than silicon in period 3.

sentences.text: The diversity of organic molecules arises from carbon's ability to form {{d5}} bond types (single, double, triple) with itself, and to bond to atoms like H, O, N, and {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Carbon can use 1, 2, or 3 bond pairs between atoms.

d6.tooltip: Common organic compounds contain C, H, O, N, and halogens.

bond_strength.title: Bond Strength Analysis
bond_strength.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of factors affecting bond strength and stability.

sentences.text: The stability order C≡C > C=C > C-C reflects that bond strength {{d1}} with the number of shared electron pairs, requiring {{d2}} energy to break multiple bonds.

d1.tooltip: More bonds = more electrons = stronger attraction.

d2.tooltip: Strong bonds need more energy to break.

sentences.text: A C-H bond (413 kJ mol⁻¹) is stronger than a C-C bond (347 kJ mol⁻¹) because hydrogen's {{d3}} allows closer approach to carbon, creating {{d4}} orbital overlap.

d4.tooltip: Closer atoms have more overlap between orbitals.

sentences.text: The C-F bond is the strongest C-X bond (485 kJ mol⁻¹) because fluorine combines a {{d5}} atomic radius with high {{d6}}, creating a short, strong polar bond.

d5.tooltip: Fluorine is in period 2, the smallest halogen.

d6.tooltip: Fluorine is the most electronegative element.

unsaturation.title: Mastering Degree of Unsaturation
unsaturation.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of unsaturation concepts and calculations.

sentences.text: A molecule with DoU = 0 is {{d1}} and contains only single C-C bonds with {{d2}} ring structures, such as hexane (C₆H₁₄).

d1.tooltip: Zero unsaturation means fully saturated with hydrogens.

d2.tooltip: Rings would add to the DoU value.

sentences.text: When nitrogen is present in a molecular formula, it {{d3}} one to the numerator of the DoU calculation because nitrogen typically forms {{d4}} bonds.

d3.tooltip: N appears as +N in the formula (2C + 2 + N - H - X) / 2.

d4.tooltip: Nitrogen is in group 15 with 5 valence electrons, forming 3 bonds.

sentences.text: Comparing cyclohexene (C₆H₁₀) and benzene (C₆H₆), cyclohexene has DoU = {{d5}} while benzene has DoU = {{d6}}, reflecting benzene's additional double bonds.

d5.tooltip: One ring + one double bond = 2 units of unsaturation.

d6.tooltip: One ring + three double bonds = 4 units of unsaturation.

structural_isomers.title: Complete Isomer Analysis
structural_isomers.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of all structural isomer types.

sentences.text: When asked to identify isomer types, first check if the {{d1}} are the same, then compare whether the difference is in {{d2}}, position, or functional group.

d1.tooltip: This is the first requirement for isomers.

d2.tooltip: Skeletal isomers differ in backbone arrangement.

sentences.text: The number of possible isomers {{d3}} as the number of carbon atoms increases, which is why C₅H₁₂ has {{d4}} isomers while C₄H₁₀ has only 2.

d3.tooltip: More carbons = more ways to arrange them.

sentences.text: Propanal (CH₃CH₂CHO) and propanone (CH₃COCH₃) are {{d5}} isomers with formula C₃H₆O, containing an {{d6}} group and a ketone group respectively.

d5.tooltip: Different functional groups: aldehyde vs ketone.

d6.tooltip: The -CHO suffix indicates an aldehyde group.
